body:
i have the very same problem. did you manage to find a workarround?
pwsh 7.1.3

i figured that it disappears when running in an "measure-command" scriptblock.

Is the linked list handing out raw _pointers_ when enumerated? I guess that sort of makes sense... Yeah, guess the formatter just straight up doesn't expect that.
Get-Error results ```powershell Type : System.Management.Automation.CmdletInvocationException ErrorRecord : Exception : Type : System.InvalidOperationException TargetSite : Name : i just figured out that you can hide the error, and it will just work

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1927076/121956892-eefcd180-cd61-11eb-9b86-42140871a298.png)
It is Formatting subsystem issue. I suppose it's not that hard to fix. (But we might have wondered about a generic support for linked lists in the language.)
Similar to #8765 but for managed pointers (in this case a ref return property like `public ref Hashtable => ref _item;`)

I believe I am encountering this as well (if not I am happy to open a new issue):

## Steps to Reproduce
```powershell
[System.Collections.Generic.LinkedList[long]]$primeSieve = [System.Collections.Generic.LinkedList[long]]::new()
$primeSieve.Add(2)
$primeSieve.Last
```

Behavior seems to have changed since PowerShell 5.1

## PowerShell 7.1.2
```text
format-default: No coercion operator is defined between types 'System.Int64&' and 'System.Object'.
```

Environment Data
```text
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.1.2
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.2
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19042
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}       
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

## PowerShell 5.1
```text
List Next Previous Value
---- ---- -------- -----
{2}                    2
```

Environment Data
```text
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      5.1.19041.1023
PSEdition                      Desktop
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   10.0.19041.1023
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```

## Workaround
In my case it was my bad, I really wanted to be doing `$primeSieve.Last.Value` anyway, which works in both versions of PowerShell, just weird to hit this and the difference between versions.
@aolszowka I can repro what you see in both 7.1.3 and 7.2.0-preview.7.  Seems to be a regression (bug) and not an enhancement request.

Looking at the docs, I can see that the `ValueRef` property seems to be new in .NET Core. So it's more something was added in .NET Core to this object type that the formatter doesn't know how to handle.

I still agree it should be fixed though; it seems like a bit of an edge case, but the formatter being entirely unable to render this kind of property is a little problematic I suppose.

I would caution against treating this like an edge case.  It is currently, but this pattern is likely to pop up with increasing frequency.

Ideally PowerShell would know how to handle these properties as if they were any other indexer with both a getter and a setter.  The setter will be a lot more challenging since iirc `SLE.Expression` will throw with a method invocation on the LHS of `Assign` but for `get` it should be able to just dereference.

(Note: if `set` is implemented, care should be taken to not allow setting to `ref readonly` returns)

I got the error "format-default: No coercion operator is defined between types 'System.Int32&' and 'System.Object'." by running the code`$l = [System.Collections.Generic.LinkedList[double]]::new(); $l.AddLast(1.3)` in the terminal.

When I wrap the function call in a `try` `catch` block (`try { $l.AddLast(1.3) } catch {}`) in the terminal it still generates the error. However, when I defined a class that extended `System.Collections.Generic.LinkedList[double]` and called `$this.AddLast` in a `try` `catch` block, within a `.ps1` script and executed it, the error wasn't thrown.

```
$PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
@rkeithhill your bug tag was removed in the same moment you have added it.

@bigboy-pdb-spam `$null = $l.AddLast(1.3)` would also solve it. It's not the method itself that's causing the error, which is why the try isn't doing anything. It happens when the return value of the method hits the formatter.

:tada:This issue was addressed in #16956, which has now been successfully released as `v7.3.0-preview.3`.:tada:

Handy links:
* [Release Notes](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/tag/v7.3.0-preview.3)
